content:
Those are your backup folders. But also, those wdseml files are only the Windows Desktop Search Email files, not your actual emails. If I remember correctly your emails live in your "Profile" folder. You need to locate your actual Thunderbird "Profile" folder in your c drive. Once your place those backup folders correctly into your profile folder, you should be able to read them all again properly. Read through the knowledge base articles on how to backup and recover your files when moving a profile. It's been a while since I looked at that, but there should be links here someplace... found 

a couple

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/products/thunderbird/install-migrate-and-update https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profile-manager-create-and-remove-thunderbird-profiles

One specific takeaway, when doing anything within your profile folders, you should have Thunderbird shut down. Not just minimized. You probably will have to also "show hidden files" in order to see all locations.

Let me know if you have more questions after reading the kb articles. Hope this helps. Marc
creator: mtz1of4

content: Look in the saved folders for the Mail\ folder and in the Mail\Local Folders folder. That is where POP and non-account folders are stored, e.g., INSURANCE and insurance.msf, etc. You can move those to the active profile in similar locations but do it when thunderbird is not running.

creator: JamesJ

content:
Yes, If you use Excel or similar spreadsheet, this macro should do it: 

 =replace(replace(XX,4,0,"-"),8,0,"-")   where XX represents the cell of the topmost phone number. The format assumes three digits for area-code followed by seven-digit number.  Then, highlight and drag down the rest of the column. If you have another spreadsheet, there is likely a similar macro to 'replace.'

content:
If you have feedback to offer, I suggest you use the feedback forum. https://connect.mozilla.org Or there is a link on the Thunderbird help menu.

However. Outgoing servers are a function of an identity in Thunderbird, not an account. As each incoming account can be configured for multiple identities and hence multiple outgoing servers, trying to shoehorn outgoing as part of incoming like is done with say outlook is not really as functional as it is with outlook which only has one identity per account.

content: Okay, I have no knowledge of Apple Mail. But, if you are using Thunderbird for Braxmail and want to keep the messages and lose the Brax account, you could (if POP account) - close Thunderbird - in file mode of OS, copy the message folders in the Mail\accountname folder to Local Folders. - then, when restarting Thunderbird, the saved messages would be there and you could remove Braxmail
creator: davidsk

content: Well, it's late Saturday night and my brain is a bit fuzzy, but I admit, I've never heard of Braxmail and would be surprised to discover that it is a Thunderbird product. But I've been wrong before. :) From what little I know, Braxmail is an email provider, possibly recommending Thunderbird? Also, to my knowledge there is no Thunderbird Apple Mail equivalent; instead, Thunderbird supports Apple mail. Setup info for that is at https://discussions.apple.com/thread/252865542 If Braxmail users use Thunderbird, then it seems there is no transfer of account needed?
